A 'chaise longue' (; Dictionary Reference:
[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/chaise+longue chaise longue] ,
"long chair") is an upholstered sofa in the shape of a chair that is long enough
to support the legs.

The architect Le Corbusier designed a Chaise Longue, which he called the LC-4
Grand Confort, that has become a classic item.

In modern French the term chaise longue can refer to any long reclining chair
such as a deckchair. A literal translation in English is "long chair". In the
United States the term lounge chair is also used to refer to any long reclining
chair. Chaise longue is sometimes incorrectly written as "".
